p.s: This chapter portrays Delaney's character development in regard of his attitude towards Mexican immigrants and shows a turning point of Delaney's bigotry.
The gap between what Delaney thinks and how he presetns himself was in previous chapters very big and he often claims to be a liberal humanist.
In this chapter however he starts to openly show his racist part of him and instinctivly acts because of his prejudices (cf. l. 39).
The use of direct speech in this case emphazises his change to beeingbeing openly and directly racist.
Because the story is told by an omniscient narrator the reader also dives in tointo the thoughts of Delaney.

The narrator often uses reported thought which lets the reader be aprt of Delaney's thoughts but still creating a distance because it is very clear that it is not the own opinion of the narrator (e.g. cf. ll. 55-59).
This clear separation and the created distance allow the reader to be part of the story but still being able to form their own opinion.
For example when Delaney is surprised about the reaction of the man to his calls because he thinks that the man is committing crime and therefore expects him to behave more shocked (cf. ll. 20f).
In this case the reader is able to follow the outturn of the situation because they know Delaney's thoughts but are also capable of noticing the differences between his expectations and the reality.

Moreover, in situations where the narrator tries to show how and for what reason the conversation escalates he uses interior monologues of Delaney and his way of building up a climax by enumerating all the reasons for his outrage (cf. ll. 49f).
Interesting in this chapter is his overwhelmed mind in the beginning and in the end of the chapter.
Both, beginning and ending, deal with the decision of whether or not building a wall around Arroyo Blanco is in his interest (cf. l. 6 and 65-69).
Through this technique, the incident with the Mexican seems to be inserted in his very ambivalent way of trying to make a decision.
It is once again a very uncomfortable experience with a Mexican.
Taking everything into account, the incident almost feels like it is utaged to help Delaney make a decision and for him to realize his changing behaviour.
Both sides for and against the wall, try to influence him in this chapter and the situation with the man makes the decision even more urgent.
